title.narrative: Provison of PPE for refuse collectors in Bolivia

description.narrative: Bolivia is facing an adverse health emergency scenario due to COVID19. This is layered on top of the political crisis with national elections looming in October 2020. In this context, urban refuse collectors in Bolivia, due to the very poor working conditions, constitute a highly vulnerable and high-risk sector. Bolivian refuse collectors, represented by the National Federation of Refuse Collectors of Bolivia (FENTRAB by its Spanish acronym), define themselves as a “strategic labour sector that is in the frontline…. tasked with keeping cities clean, preserving the health of the population… by removing discarded infected materials from hospitals”. Currently the biosecurity measures provided by the State are inadequate and refuse collectors in order to protect their lives and health must purchase their own biosecurity items (masks, gloves etc). Workers collect waste from hospitals and homes of infected families but waste of COVID19 patients is not separated or labelled. The majority are part of the informal work sector due to the outsourcing of the service and having temporary contracts. This means that social benefits, access to state health care systems and long-term insurance is not guaranteed for this sector. Affiliate local unions report increasing deaths and infection rates of their members. CAFOD partner UNITAS will work with FENTRAB to provide PPE and fumigation materials to women and men refuse collectors in capital cities and intermediate towns in the nine departments of the country.
